channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Former Egyptian Ambassador to U.S. Named Foreign Minister
item.description: Nabil Fahmy accepted the post of foreign minister on Sunday in the interim government being put in place after the removal of president Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Woman Gored During Final Bull Run in Spain
item.description: A regional health official said the 23-year-old woman was gored in the thorax and was hospitalized along with four others who were injured in the bull run.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cory Monteith, Star of Hit Show ‘Glee,’ Found Dead
item.description: Mr. Monteith, 31, who shot to fame in Fox’s TV series but was beset by fierce addiction struggles, was found dead in a hotel room in Canada on Saturday, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 2 Killed by U.S. Drone Strike in Pakistan
item.description: At least two people were killed Saturday in an American drone strike in a northwestern tribal region of Pakistan, according to intelligence officials.
item.dc:creator: By IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Turkish Lawmakers Move to Curb Army’s Political Power
item.description: The Turkish Parliament on Saturday amended an army regulation that had paved the way for military intervention in politics.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Israel Airstrike Targeted Advanced Missiles That Russia Sold to Syria, U.S. Says
item.description: American officials said Israel carried out an air attack in Syria this month that targeted advanced antiship cruise missiles sold to the Syria government by Russia.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Japan and China Trade Sharp Words Over Islands
item.description: The heated exchange over disputed territory started with a Japanese report accusing China of aggressive maritime tactics and was stark evidence of two nations uneasy about each other’s military capabilities.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Brazilian President’s Attempts to Placate Protesters Backfire
item.description: Nearly every step President Dilma Rousseff has taken has backfired, increasing public dissatisfaction with her performance.
item.dc:creator: By LARRY ROHTER
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff has announced a series of initiatives to address protesters’ demands. The latest, a plan to improve medical care by sending 10,000 doctors to underserved areas, set off anger because most of the physicians would be foreign hires.

item.title: As Mystery Illness Stalks Its Young, India Intensifies Search for a Killer
item.description: A brain swelling that is infecting the country’s youth, throwing them into comas and killing seemingly healthy children, often within hours, has stumped the country’s physicians.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Mohan Kumar checked on a patient at Sri Krishna Medical College Hospital in Muzaffarpur, India.

item.title: 16 More Killed in Wave of Bombings in Iraq
item.description: The late-night blast in Kirkuk ripped through the Classico Cafe as patrons were enjoying tea and water pipes hours after the sunset meal that breaks the daylong Ramadan fast.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Financial Lifesaver Thrown by Creditors Weighs Cyprus Down
item.description: A tough rescue package seems to be turning a banking crisis into a broader recession, spreading the pain instead of containing it.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Cyprus, fears of a bank run led to currency restrictions and a harsh bailout that have sent shock waves through the economy.

item.title: Lithium-Ion Battery Is Not Suspected in the Fire on a Boeing 787 at Heathrow
item.description: The incident took place about two months after 787s returned to the skies after being grounded because of hazards with a new type of battery.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW
item.media:description: The Queen of Sheba, a Boeing 787 Dreamliner that caught fire at Heathrow Airport on Friday. This video still shows some of the foam used by firefighters.

item.title: Nations Buying as Hackers Sell Flaws in Computer Code
item.description: Governments pay hundreds of thousands of dollars to learn about and exploit weaknesses in the computer systems of foreign adversaries.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luigi Auriemma looks for flaws in computer codes that his customers can exploit.

item.title: Leaving the Land: Pitfalls Abound in China’s Push From Farm to City
item.description: Even a showpiece project in Shaanxi Province shows flaws in China’s urbanization drive, including high electricity costs and a lack of jobs in the new towns.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Darfur Attack Kills 7 in Force Sent to Sudan By the U.N.
item.description: The attack was the deadliest single attack on the international force in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Wheels: Mercedes Grand Prix Car Smashes Auction Records
item.description: With two of the car’s former drivers in attendance at the auction, the 1954 Mercedes-Benz W196 racer sold for nearly $30 million.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The Swiss Grand Prix on Aug. 22, 1954, won by Juan Manuel Fangio.

item.title: The Lede: Malala Yousafzai, Girl Shot by Taliban, Makes Appeal at U.N.
item.description: On her 16th birthday, Malala Yousafzai spoke at the United Nations and called on world leaders to make education available and compulsory for every child.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: The Lede: Parents Mourn Photographer Killed in Cairo
item.description: As the parents of Ahmed Assem, a 26-year-old photographer for a Muslim Brotherhood newspaper who was killed on Monday, mourned his death, Egyptian bloggers discovered disparaging remarks about Christians on the dead man’s Facebook page.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: An image of a graffiti tribute to Ahmed Assem, a photographer for a Muslim Brotherhood newspaper who was killed on Monday in Cairo, posted on Facebook by his brother.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Snowden
item.description: The Lede is following updates on Edward J. Snowden in Moscow, where the first image of him emerged from a meeting with rights groups.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:credit: Tanya Lokshina/Human Rights Watch, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo Airport on Friday, with Sarah Harrison of WikiLeaks at left.

item.title: City in Russia Unable to Kick Asbestos Habit
item.description: To residents of Asbest in Russia’s Ural Mountains, living with a pervasive carcinogen is the alternative to having no livelihood at all.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Olga Kravets for The New York Times
item.media:description: Every weekday afternoon in Asbest, Russia, miners set explosions in an asbestos strip mine, sending out clouds of carcinogenic dust.

item.title: A Two-Doctor Family’s Prosperity and Routine Are Shaken by War
item.description: One family’s story illustrates how war, displacement and currency collapse have upended a professional class that was proportionally one of the Arab world’s largest.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Syria Weighs Its Tactics as Pillars of Its Economy Continue to Crumble
item.description: Syria is increasingly isolated in the face of a growing economic crisis, more reliant than ever on credit from its main remaining allies.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The Grand Bazaar in Damascus. The value of Syria’s currency has plunged, so goods are costlier.

item.title: Dozens Injured in Northern Ireland as Protestants Riot
item.description: Northern Ireland’s police commander blamed leaders of the Orange Order brotherhood for inciting running street battles in two parts of Belfast that lasted six hours and subsided early Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Police officers, with reinforcements from across Britain, were deployed in north Belfast as Orange Order members rioted.

item.title: Iraq Says It Can’t Halt Arms to Syria
item.description: Iraq’s foreign minister said his nation condemned the transfer of weapons from Iran to Syria through its airspace, but could not stop it from happening.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Loose Equipment Cited in Train Crash in France
item.description: The train accident outside Paris on Friday that killed at least six people and injured dozens of others was linked to a loose rail joint.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: French officials said the death toll at Brétigny-sur-Orge station might increase when the train wreckage was removed.
